author: keysworld253
body:
I have mixed feeling on selling prior to earnings. Beucase of exactly what happened. If youre buying weekly options then yeah, youre playing with fire holding options through earnings. But if you have options contracts that has a lot of time left after the earnings call then you have time to recover. If your options contracts has months left until expiration then holding through earnings is not going to hurt you too bad. I bought calls on AMD at the end of June and they were down 50-80% leading up to earnings. I have been slowly (maybe prematurely) selling my calls all for profits of 150-300%. My calls expired in September, November, and December. I like to stagger mine. 

With that being said, I think people grossly missunderstood the position AMD is in. The signs were all there. Technically AMD was finishing up making a cup-and-handle formation. Say what you want about charts but they are a great indication of market sentiment and direction. 

Fundamentally, AMD has been stealing market share quite aggressively from Intel. Intel's last earnings call was a huge sign. Literally every semi-company is reporting great numbers except Intel. Intel's last earnings call was not very positive. AMD's revenue has been growing rapidly over the last year. On top of the company actually hitting on all cylinders, the semiconductor industry as a whole is rapidly growing. Demand is severely outstripping supply. Then you have another positive catalyst with the potential of the Xilinx purchase. Frankly, I see no reason why China will approve it, but I have been wrong in the past. 

Even after earning, with the astronomical increase in volume when AMD broke the $96 price point. That was a huge buy signal since it was the completion of the cup-and-handle pattern. If you would have loaded up on September calls after earning after the huge first day run up, you would be sitting nicely.

author: Maximus_Aurelius
body:
Good analysis. A few slight clarifications:

> They acquired Xilinx so they are well positioned to kill it in the ARM server market

XLNX makes FPGAs, not ARM server chips. FPGAs do lots of different thing (they can and will be used in servers but they are so much more). And they bring a deep software engineering bench that AMD has often lacked over the years, so the tie up ought to work out well along several lines. 

> now that TSMC is being used by Intel, Apple, AMD, and anyone who needs 5nm, it may be difficult to keep up with demand until the new TSMC fabs come online

Apple will always get first crack at the new stuff because they essentially pay TSMC a premium for it and subsidize its R&D for the newest nodes. Intel has announced a need to turn to TSMC for fabrication of at least some of its leading edge chips, due to its own technical problems. 

However, between AMD and Intel, AMD will be given preference. The reason is simple. Intel has declared open warfare on TSMC with the announcement of its “IDM 2.0” initiative, which aims to open Intel’s fabrication facilities to third parties — essentially, they want to take a chunk of TSMC’s foundry business. As a result, while TSMC will supply Intel to a reasonable extent, they will almost certainly give AMD preference over Intel, as a way to check Intel’s ambitions. 

In other words, TSMC says if you want to cut into our core business (foundry), we will enable AMD to cut into your core business (x86 server and laptop CPUs) by making sure they have whatever they need on the fabrication side of things.
